text: in this video I will be showing you how
to create this a unique looking coffee
table not only is its work surface made
of burnt woods from a euro pellets
capsulated in epoxy resin
but its main body is also made up of a
sliced a barrel which houses a bit of
electronics in order to light up the
coffee table with LEDs through this
combination of materials this coffee
table is truly special and also offers a
bit of storage space for all kinds of
remotes so let's not waste any more time
and let me show you what steps are
required to create your own let's get
started this video is sponsored by JL
CPCB who currently gives out piece B
coupons to customers who follow the
guidelines stated in the video
description so with or without PCB
coupon feel free to upload yo Gerber
files today and order your PCBs from jl
CPC beer for cheap we started off with
the euro pallets from which we salvaged
the woods for the projects by utilising
a crowbar pliers and a lot of force and
what we have learned from this
experience is that such wood salvaging
is only worth it if you get a euro
pallets for free otherwise we would
recommend spying woods to save quite a
bit of time but anyway next we marked a
59 centimeter length on to 7 pieces of
the woods cut them with a jigsaw and
afterwards got rid of the rough surfaces
and edges by using an orbital sander
to give the woods a more interesting
look though we also burned the debates
with a propane torch
and as soon as that was done we brought
in the five pre-cut pieces of textured
coated boards with those measurements
which will form d casting modes for our
work surface so we preach world's a few
dozens of holes through the side pieces
into the bottom piece and combine them
mechanically with wood screws after we
sealed all the edges and corners with
silicone once the mold was complete and
all silicone lines were smooth doubts it
was time to bring in a canister of
Charlie which is a special type of oil
that prevents the epoxy resin from
sticking to the woods as soon as the
lubrication was completes we positioned
the seven wood pieces inside the molds
one after the other and then secure them
in place from the bottom with wood
screws here are by the way the
measurements for our work surface in
case you're interested but anyway at
this point I grabbed the two-component
epoxy resin of which I created a three
liter batch inside a plastic buckets
according to the mix ratio given by the
manufacturer we then slowly poured this
resin inside the molds and after popping
all the rising air bubbles will be heat
gun we let it dry for 48 hours during
that time we started working on our old
barrel which came with pretty standard
dimensions first off we determined and
marked a middle line on the top and
bottom piece through the help other
threats and then connected those lines
on the main body of the barrel by
following those lines with an angle
grinder it was actually not that
difficult to cut the barrel into halves
in less than 10 minutes and after
cleaning the inside of the barrel and
getting rid of all the sharp edges we
chose a suitable spots for opening
markets and removed the barrel sheets
moved the angle grinder as well after
doing a bit more raus treatments
then positions - hinges onto the door to
build their mounting holes and lock them
in position with rivets as soon as that
was done I grabbed the small wood handle
I got from the home improvement store
Burnett's which I may have overdone a
bits created holes for it in the door
and secured it to it move the given
screws then we marked the holes for the
door onto the barrel twilled them and
secure it in place with more rivets the
only thing our door was lacking was a
limiter which we added under one handle
screw heads and thus we finally got more
storage space for the coffee table
at this point we brought in square steel
and 40 nuts and an m14 threaded rods out
of which we ultimately created Lille X
for the coffee table to start off we
desperately tried determining a suitable
angle for the legs and finally settled
on around 56 degrees after a bit of
experimenting that means we could mark a
fitting length on one of them at that
angle and thus mark this twenty point
five centimeter length on to the
three-year other square steel pieces in
order to reach an oval heights of 43
centimeters for the coffee table after
then cutting these squares deals with
the angle grinder we continued to use it
to remove a bit of material at the left
and right side of 4 and 40 nuts so that
I fit perfectly inside the hollow square
steel this was important because
otherwise we would not have been able to
wealthy nuts inside them and as soon as
one nuts was welded to one square steel
more or less successfully we made
everything a bit more prettier with the
angle grinder treatments and continued
by marking before mounting holes for the
legs 12 centimeter supports from the top
and bottom piece after then drilling 14
millimeter holes for them we cut smaller
pieces of the threaded rods screwed them
inside the legs and finally secure them
to the barrel with two more washers and
nevah m40 nuts on the insights now our
coffee table was finally able to stand
on its own which means it was time for
the electronics since we didn't want to
have a wire permanently connected to it
we decided on a 12 volts battery
solution it connects to generic 12 foods
RGB W LED strip controller and thus an
RGB W LED strip through a simple power
switch to charge it I use the generic 12
foods battery charger whose mains input
I wired up soon IEC connector mounted in
the barrel sheets and whose charge
status LED gets positioned right next to
the connector to implement this plan I
firstly gots this intelligent charger
that supports 12 volt batteries and can
output up to 1 amp of current after
unboxing it's removing its enclosure and
having a closer look at its main
circuits I connected its outputs to
another 12 volt battery and hooked up
its inputs to mains voltage and sure
enough the red LED lit up and the
batteries started charging move around 1
amp so I removed the status LED from the
PCB R in order to reconnect it with a
bit of extension while to later position
it's inside the barrel sheets and after
doing a quick tests I positioned the
naked charger circuits inside a
distribution box pushed all over 3 wires
to the outsides and closed it up now
back to the barrel where we firstly
marked a location for the IEC connector
the 12 will power switch and the status
LED after completing the cutouts for the
connector we secure it in place with
rivets twilled the remaining 2 holes and
then I continued by soldering a PE wire
to the IEC connector which I hooked up
to the barrels metal body with the power
switch for safety reasons next I added
the mains input wires of the charger to
the connector as well as why
for the power switch include the status
LED in place last but not least for the
wire ring a crimp cable shoes to the
battery wires and connected all wires to
one another with Vargo terminals
according to the scheme I showed you a
minute ago after then hooking up the
battery as well as the RGB W LED strip
controller everything seemed to work
correctly which means it was time for me
to secure the LED strip all around the
barrel and with that step being
completed the electronic system was done
and thus next we checked on our work
surface which partly turned out great
but on other sections created lots of
bubbles and white foam due to the
reaction with the woods to still create
a good-looking surface finish we firstly
removed all the screws from the side
pieces and then Hammer them off the
epoxy resin at this point we used a
router to round off the edges of the top
sides and then continued by hitting the
surface with the orbital sander and pide
grits sandpaper this sanding helped a
lots to get a smoother surface but we
decided to do this properly by
incrementally increasing the sandpaper
grits up to P a mm that means the rough
sandpaper grits were all done with a
machine while we had to use a lot of
force water and patience for the final
sandpaper grits and after three hours of
sanding the work surface looked pretty
good so we removed the last piece of the
molds with wood wedges and a hammer and
continued by marking the outline of the
barrel onto the bottom side of the work
surface the last step was to move this
outline five millimeter deep and finally
positioning the work surface on top of
the barrel to complete this unique
coffee table I hope you enjoyed this
video and maybe it inspired you to
create something similar on your own if
so don't forget to Like share subscribe
stay creative and I will see you next
time
